title: 107_s79
content: The "Safe Schools Act of 2001" may be cited as the Safe Schools Act. It focuses on ensuring safety in schools. Amendments to the Gun-Free Schools Act of 1994 under the Safe Schools Act of 2001 include changing the title to "Safe Schools," updating the year to 2001, and adding provisions related to possession of illegal drugs on school property. Amendments to the Gun-Free Schools Act of 1994 under the Safe Schools Act of 2001 include defining "weapon" and "illegal drug" as well as "illegal drug paraphernalia." The Safe Schools Act of 2001 amended the Gun-Free Schools Act of 1994 to include definitions of "weapon," "illegal drug," and "illegal drug paraphernalia." The term "felonious quantities of an illegal drug" was also defined in the amendment. The Safe Schools Act of 2001 amended the Gun-Free Schools Act of 1994 by removing subsection (f) and making changes to sections 14602(a) and 14603. The Safe Schools Act of 2001 amended the Gun-Free Schools Act of 1994 by removing subsection (f) and making changes to sections 14602(a) and 14603. The amendments include prohibiting possessing illegal drugs or paraphernalia on school property or in vehicles operated by schools or local educational agencies. States have 2 years from enactment to comply with the new requirements. The Secretary of Education will submit reports to Congress on discipline approaches for children with disabilities and compliance with the requirements of the Act.
